text:
hey everyone welcome to Pai's kitchen today for 
the first time in the history of Pai's kitchen

I am sharing with you one of my mother-in-law's 
recipe so this dish is sort of her signature dish

she makes it all the time and it's my husband's 
favorite way to have fish it's a pretty classic

dish too it's steamed fish with black bean 
sauce and it's just one of those things that's

really quick simple and healthy so it's a perfect 
family-friendly weeknight meal let's get started

so the fish that my mother-in-law uses for this 
is always black cod also known as sable fish or in

Thai this would be Blackie Mac because it's super 
oily and tender and just works beautifully but you

can also use any other tender mild flavored white 
fish like ling cod works really well too so just

some a couple of steaks about an inch thick okay 
so we'll let that sit for now and then I'm going

to make the fish sauce but without fish sauce 
you're about to see so in the plate then you're

going to use to steam the fish okay so it's got 
to be heat proof and it's got to have some depth

to it because when you steam there's gonna be 
all sorts of liquid collected so nothing that's

completely flat so I've got some soy sauce going 
in here and some Chinese cooking wine and this

is my own little addition that's a little more 
complexity I'm some sugar to balance out the salt

and some white pepper and then I'm just gonna give 
this a stir to get most of the sugar dissolved it

doesn't have to be completely dissolved and 
you know this dish is a pretty classic dish

and everyone's got a slightly different way of 
doing it so if you make a fish with black beans

and you've got a different method share with 
us in the comments below we'd love to know how

you make it okay so now the fish is gonna go in 
there I'm just gonna put that in there and then

give it a flip yeah that in there give it a flip 
and you know what I'm gonna do I'm going to move

them so they are diagonal to the plate because 
that's just prettier looking so I'm gonna let

this marinate in the fridge 15 minutes on one 
side I'm gonna give it a flip let it marinate

another 15 minutes on the other side meanwhile 
let's make all the other stuff that's gonna go

on top so let's talk black beans here so this is 
Chinese black beans which is actually soy beans

that have been fermented and they turn black in 
the process they're quite salty it's really widely

available at any Asian grocery stores I have given 
this a rinse so I just put it in a little strainer

and run some water through it to wash all sort 
of the excess salt it reduces the saltiness a

little bit okay so now that you've got that I am 
going to chop it in to create sort of a mixture

with some garlic and ginger so I've chopped some 
garlic and ginger here put these in and chop away

and I should have picked a bigger 
cutting board yes but this one's so cute

okay so that's really all you're going for 
you're just getting the beans to break up into

small chunks and get it all mixed up a little bit 
nice and easy all right so then the fish is done

marinating and by the way you can put more black 
beans or less black beans with your first time

maybe use a little less cuz it does have a bit 
of a funky smell you might not be used to some

people like more intense you can put more but 
just be careful it's salty so the more you put

the saltier it's gonna be so if you like more 
black beans maybe cut down on the soy sauce a

little and so now I'm just gonna put this paste 
on the fish not really a pace this crumble it's

like a crumb topping on the fish and just press 
it on give it a final douse you don't have to

do this I just just makes me feel better to 
do it okay whoo and one more thing this is

again my own little trick so I yeah I modified 
my mother-in-law recipe a little bit just gonna

add some extra ginger in the sauce just cuz I 
like that extra ginger flavor because I'm this

way as the fish steamed the ginger will steam 
right into the sauce all right let's get the

steamer ready so I've got the steamer heating up 
right here now with the fish as you can see there

isn't much sauce right now but trust me once 
the fish steams the fish will release quite a

bit of liquid but I don't want too much liquid 
so I'm gonna cover this with parchment paper to

prevent the condensation from the lid to get 
on top of the fish now I have a little trick

for you so see when you get parchment paper 
out it likes to curl like that so to prevent

it from curling what you do is you just crumple 
it into a ball and then when you stretch it out

it will kind of mold to whatever shape you want 
it to go into and just like that and then this

way you're not gonna get too much water drifting 
you don't want to like completely seal it because

you want to allow the steam to come in but you 
know a little umbrella is what you're going for

yes careful don't burn yourself okay so this 
will take for the size of my fish about 15

minutes if you got something thinner check 
in at 12 and if you have a meat thermometer

you're going for a minimum internal temperature 
of 145 degrees Fahrenheit all righty you tada

up my paper look how beautiful that is see 
there's so much more liquid now and that's

whip the paper so you can imagine Li how much 
water that would be we didn't put the paper on

now because we've diluted our sauce a little 
bit I'm going to taste the sauce just to see

where it's at in terms of saltiness mmm perfect 
goo that's gingery now at this point if you find

that there's too much water that's gotten into 
a little bland you can that just a touch more

soy sauce touch more sugar just to to perfect 
the sauce flavor a little bit now to add some

color to this I'm gonna sprinkle on some green 
onions which instantly makes everything look

better and if you happen to have something red 
in the kitchen throw it on to why not this is not

the most colorful of dishes right so whatever you 
can do to help now I'm going to close the lid let

that green onion just steam in the residual 
steam for 30 seconds or so just to you know

activate all those oniony flavor and then you're 
done get your rice ready look at that fish oh my

god now it's just careful especially if you 
are using black cod there are pin bones that

sort of is spread out in between the fillet you 
grew up eating bone-in fish you kind of know the

drill but you know mmm the smell of all of the 
black beans and the ginger and garlic so good

it's like the flavor of comforting home cooking 
like it's not a strongly flavored dish one way or

another but it's just well balanced with the 
saltiness and sweetness and that little funk

from the black beans the fish I love black cod 
it's so moist and juicy and tender and this is

also really forgiving fish like if you overcook 
it a little bit it's not gonna go dry and tough

on you another reason why I love black cod so I 
hope you give this recipe a try oh and by the way

for our patreon members in the show after the 
show I'm gonna talk to you about how I people

might go about making this dish we have a bit of 
a different technique when it comes to steaming

fish so we'll talk about that and the recipe 
as always will be on Pais kitchen comm and

when you make it definitely send me a photo on 
Facebook Twitter or tag me on Instagram and if

you have not subscribed to the show make sure 
you do so you don't miss an episode and click

the bell icon as well that is how you will get 
a notification when I post a new video and thank

you as always for watching and I will see you 
next time for your next English just adventure
you
